texts.shortText: Previously incorrectly identified as Marphysa sanguinea  (which remains a valid, but not South African species) and then described as a new, local species M. elityeni, but this has now been combined with M. haemasoma on the basis of genetic evidence.

Large, dark-red worm with distinctly flattened body. Head with two swollen semicircular palps and five pale finger-like antennae with darker tips. Mouthparts, if everted, with large strongly-toothed jaws. Anterior limbs without gills, but those on most of body with large red gills, each with six long finger-like branches (first gill and last 13 have only one branch).
Body length about 300 mm, can reach 470 mm.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Probably Namibia to about East London, but Namibian samples were not included in the recent genetic studies and may turn out to represent yet another species. Confirmed distribution Saldanha to Algoa Bay.
A large species typically found burrowing in gravel in boulder fields in the low intertidal, where they can be quite common. Sought after as bait.
Little is known about reproduction in this species, but sexes are separate. Some other Marphysa species lay eggs in gelatinous egg sacs. Larval development is almost certainly planktonic.

Several other Marphysa species are found in the region and are distinguished mostly by microscopic details of the setae and gill filaments. All are described in detail in the paper by Kara et al. cited below. Can also be confused with the Giant wonderworm Eunice aphroditois which occurs in the same habitat, but Eunice have a pair of tentacular cirri on the first body segment that are absent in Marphysa.

Branch G, Griffiths CL, Branch M, Beckley L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 68).

Day, JH (1967). A Monograph on the Polychaeta of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London, part1 Errantia (p. 396).

Kara, J, Molina-Acevedo, IC, Zanol, J, Simon, C & Idris, I (2020). Morphological and molecular systematic review of Marphysa Quatrefages, 1865 (Annelida: Eunicidae) species from South Africa. PeerJ, 8, e10076.

Lewis, C & Karageorgopoulos, P (2008). A new species of Marphysa (Eunicidae) from the western Cape of South Africa. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 88(2), 277-287.

Simon, C, Kara, J, du Toit, A, van Rensburg, H, Naidoo, C & Matthee, CA (2021). Reeling them in: taxonomy of marine annelids used as bait by anglers in the Western Cape Province, South Africa. PeerJ, 9, e11847.
